section.text: This document should now be complete and accurate, however, please feel free to consult the JSCoverage documentation.

item.heading: Introduction
item.text: JSCover is a tool that measures code coverage for JavaScript programs. It is based on the popular JSCoverage, with the C++/SpiderMonkey instrumentation replaced with Java/Rhino.

JSCover works by adding instrumentation to JavaScript code before it is executed in a web browser. JSCover provides several alternative ways of doing this:
The simplest method is to use the server mode, a simple web server that instruments JavaScript code as it is served.
Alternatively, you can use the file-system mode program to generate instrumented JavaScript files.
Finally, the server mode can be run with the --proxy option to act as a proxy server which instruments any JavaScript code proxied through it.

The server (both web and proxy) has two advantages:
can store coverage reports to the filesystem*
can include unloaded/untested JavaScript in the report
* It's possible to store a report to the file-system as described below.

item.heading: Packaging
item.text: JSCover comes packaged in two JARs. The first option is preferred to avoid class-path issues, especially as JSCover may be using a non-standard version on Rhino (e.g. built from trunk or patched).

ul.li: JSCover.jar which must have all dependent JARs available in the same directory

item.text: The JARs are available in the ZIP download file under the directory target/dist
The maven release includes the JSCover-all.jar JAR.
The best way to get started is to run the the examples included in the distribution.
item.heading: Server
Start The Server
item.text:
Run jscover-server.bat or jscover-server.sh. The contents are: java -jar target/dist/JSCover-all.jar -ws --document-root=doc/example --report-dir=target This will start a web server, and the JSCover interface can be loaded by going to http://localhost:8080/jscoverage.html.
You can then enter the URL http://localhost:8080/index.html in the URL input box and click on the Open in frame button.

item.heading: Load The Test Page
item.text: To automatically load the web-page without entering it in the URL section, got to http://localhost:8080/jscoverage.html?index.html.

item.heading: Run Tests
item.text: Tests that exercise the JavaScript can now be run. As long as you do not reload the jscoverage.html page, the coverage report statistics are cumulative.

item.heading: View The Coverage Summary
item.text: To see a summary of the coverage, click the Summary tab. Note, you can change the sorting order by clicking on the Coverage, Branch or Function links:

item.heading: View Uncovered Lines
item.text: To see uncovered lines, check the Show missing statements column check-box:

item.heading: View The Source
item.text: To view the source, click on the script-name link in the File column (shown above) - the result is shown below.

item.heading: View Uncovered Branches
item.text: To determine which branch path was not covered click on the info link.

item.heading: Store The Report
item.text:
To store the report, click on the Store tab and then the Store Report button.
The report does not work in Google Chrome when viewed using a file: URL. Either use an ordinary web server to serve the report (JSCover comes with a simple web server) or start Google Chrome with the --allow-file-access-from-files command line option.

item.heading: Stop The Server
item.text: To stop the server, click on the Store tab and then the Stop Server button.
Alternatively, the server can be stopped by entering the URI path /stop (for example http://localhost:8080/stop).

item.heading: About Page
item.text: Version and other information can be viewed by clicking on the About tab:

item.heading: Proxy
item.text: The proxy mode operates in a similar fashion to the server. To demonstrate the proxy functionality locally, perform the following steps or see here for a working web-driver example.

item.heading: Edit Your Hosts File
item.text: Edit your host file adding the following entry 127.0.0.1 localhost-proxy

item.heading: Configure Browser To Use The Proxy
item.text: Set the proxy-host to localhost and the proxy-port to 3128. Make sure 'localhost' is in the proxy-bypass list, and that 'localhost-proxy' is not.

item.heading: Start A Web-Server
item.text: This is the web-server we'll be accessing via the proxy. Run web-server.bat or web-server.sh. The contents are: java -cp target/dist/JSCover-all.jar jscover.server.SimpleWebServer . 8080

item.heading: Start JSCover as a proxy
item.text: Run jscover-proxy.bat or jscover-proxy.sh. The contents are: $ java -jar target/dist/JSCover-all.jar -ws --proxy --port=3128 --report-dir=target
Point your browser to: http://localhost-proxy:8080/jscoverage.html?doc/example/index.html.
The site can now be instrumented in a similar way to the server mode in the previous section.

item.heading: File System
item.text: Run jscover-filesystem.bat or jscover-filesystem.sh. The contents are: java -jar target/dist/JSCover-all.jar -fs doc/example target/example This will recursively copy all the resources from doc/example to target/example, and create the JSCover files (e.g. jscoverage.html) at target/example.

This can either be via the file-system, but is not recommended due to security restrictions
. You would enter something like the following in your address bar: file:///C:/Java/JSCover/target/example/jscoverage.html?index.html

item.heading: Save The Coverage JSON
item.text: The file-system mode web-UI does not have a Store Report button, however the report can still be saved to the file-system. The JSON for the report can be generated by calling the jscoverage_serializeCoverageToJSON() function.
WebDriver String json = (String)((JavascriptExecutor) webClient).executeScript("return jscoverage_serializeCoverageToJSON();");
Selenium String json = selenium.getEval("selenium.browserbot.getUserWindow().jscoverage_serializeCoverageToJSON();");

Once the JSON is available in your browser driver, it can then be saved to the file-system using that environment's file-system API. The source JavaScript can then be copied across to the original-src directory of the reports folder.

item.heading: Enable JSCover Web UI
item.text: If you want to view the report using JSCover's web-UI, you can generate the other report files (jscoverage.js, jscoverage.html, jscoverage.css, jscoverage-highlight.css, jscoverage-ie.css, jscoverage-throbber.gif) in server mode. The jscoverage.js file generated in server mode has the code jscoverage_isReport = true; at the end which is required to view the stored report.

item.heading: Non-Instrumenting Web Server
item.text: To avoid any file-system issues (described above), JSCover comes with a simple non-instrumenting web server. Run it from the distribution's root directory: java -cp target/dist/JSCover-all.jar jscover.server.SimpleWebServer . 8080 Then point your browser at: http://localhost:8080/doc/example-qunit/out/jscoverage.html?test/index.html The UI interaction should now be the same as for the server except for the missing Store tab.

item.heading: Encoding
item.text:
The encoding defaults to the platform's default encoding which is usually what you want. To specify an encoding, add the JVM option -Dfile.encoding=ENCODING. For example: java -Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 -jar JSCover-all.jar [OPTIONS]... To see the available encodings (as well as the current default) run JSCover with options -h encoding
java -jar JSCover-all.jar -h encoding

item.heading: Enable Assertions
item.text: To help detect errors while running JSCover, run the JVM with assertions enabled (JVM flag -ea). For example: java -ea -jar JSCover-all.jar -ws --port=80 --no-instrument=lib --no-instrument=test

item.heading: Java Regular Expressions
item.text:
All regular expression functionality is provided by the JVM. Further documentation can be found at:
Pattern

item.heading: Program Exit Status
item.text: If any exceptions were thrown, the program will exit with an exit status of 1.

item.heading: Proxy Mode
item.text: In proxy mode, JSCover operates as a HTTP proxy server and instruments the specified JavaScript served through it.

item.heading: Translating a URI to a File Path
item.text:
When operating as a proxy, it is possible to have a URI which doesn't match the the file system path. This is normally not a problem, as the JavaScript contents will be saved to the file-system using the URI. However, there a two potential problems to be handled:
The URI contains characters not compatible with the file-system
If the --include-unloaded-js option has been specified, the actual file represented by the URI will not be detected as having already been included, and will appear a second time with no coverage.
An example to convert '/exclude/include/code.js' to '/include/code.js' would be: --uri-to-file-matcher=/exclude(.*) --uri-to-file-replace=$1

item.heading: Storing reports
item.text:
The store button triggers the POSTing of the coverage data to the server in JSON format. The following will then occur:
If a JSON file, jscoverage.json, already exists, the coverage data will be merged
If no JSON file exists, but --include-unloaded-js is present, all un-loaded JavaScript files will be merged with the submitted JSON and saved to the report
If neither of the above is true, the raw JSON is stored

item.heading: Programmatic Report Storage
item.text: It is not necessary that your test suite be executed within the jscoverage.html web interface to store a coverage report. The URL of the test suite can simply be loaded directly in a web browser.
The example in doc/example-jsunit/ demonstrates storing coverage reports programmatically.

item.heading: File Mode

--no-instrument-reg=URL None

--exclude=PATH None Copies SOURCE-DIRECTORY to DESTINATION-DIRECTORY recursively, but does not copy SOURCE-DIRECTORY/PATH. PATH must be a complete path relative to SOURCE-DIRECTORY. PATH can be a file or a directory (in which case the directory and its entire contents are skipped). This option may be given multiple times.

Same as '--exclude=PATH', except PATH is interpreted as a regular expression
--no-branch N/A Turn off branch coverage data collection

--local-storage N/A
Save and load coverage data from HTML5 local storage. See the section on HTML5 local storage for more information

Use the specified JavaScript version; valid values for VERSION are 1.0, 1.1, 1.2, ..., 1.8.

The first step is to add instrumentation to your JavaScript code. You do this by executing JSCover with two arguments: java -jar JSCover-all.jar -fs SOURCE-DIRECTORY DESTINATION-DIRECTORY

SOURCE-DIRECTORY is the directory containing the JavaScript code to be instrumented, and DESTINATION-DIRECTORY is the name of the directory to which JSCover should output the instrumented code. The JSCover program will create DESTINATION-DIRECTORY if necessary and (recursively) copy SOURCE-DIRECTORY to DESTINATION-DIRECTORY, instrumenting any files ending with a .js extension.

The directory structure under SOURCE-DIRECTORY will be preserved, so that if you have a file SOURCE-DIRECTORY/dir/index.html referencing the script SOURCE-DIRECTORY/dir/script.js, then JSCover will create a copy of the HTML file at DESTINATION-DIRECTORY/dir/index.html and an instrumented version of the script at DESTINATION-DIRECTORY/dir/script.js. In addition, JSCover will create a file called jscoverage.html which will be used to execute the instrumented code. java -jar JSCover-all.jar -fs SOURCE-DIRECTORY DESTINATION-DIRECTORY

For the example code in the doc/example/ directory, you can execute the following command line from the top-level directory of the JSCover distribution: java -jar JSCover-all.jar -fs doc/example doc/instrumented
This will create the directory doc/instrumented/ and place an instrumented copy of the code from doc/example/ in doc/instrumented/.

item.heading: Introduction
item.text: Specifying local storage mode --local-storage makes use of HTML5's local storage feature to store coverage data between page loads without the need of iframes or JavaScript-opened windows.

This can be especially useful for existing automated tests against a web-server, as the coverage data can be collected using the existing tests with only the following modifications:
either the JavaScript must be pre-instrumented using the file-system mode or the browser can use the JSCover proxy
store the coverage results at the end of the test suite
clear JSCover's HTML5 local storage localStorage['jscover']

item.heading: Clearing HTML5 Local Storage
Example
item.text: For a full working example using a recorded Selenium IDE test, see the 'examples/localStorage-server' folder of the ZIP distribution.
The 'examples/localStorage-proxy' folder contains a similar example in proxy mode.

item.heading: How does it work
item.text:
When the local storage switch, --local-storage, is supplied, some extra JavaScript is added to the instrumented JavaScript. From the source it can be seen that the following occurs:
When the page and JavaScript loads, it attempts to load the coverage data from HTML5 local storage
When the page exits, it attempts to save the coverage data to HTML5 local storage

item.heading: Default Logging
item.text: A log file, jscover.log, may be produced in the output directory if any message logging occurred.
The logging level can be altered as described above use the --log=LEVEL flag in the server mode and file mode usage sections.

item.heading: Advanced Logging
item.text: JSCover's allows finer control of logging by via the JVM option -Djava.util.logging.configuration.file=FILE. For example: java -Djava.util.logging.configuration.file=log.properties -jar JSCover-all.jar [OPTIONS]... A sample property file, log.properties, is included in the root directory of the ZIP distribution. Specifying this JVM option will turn off the default programmatic logging.

Full Java documentation of the configuration of property file can be found in:
ConsoleHandler
FileHandler
Level
Logging package summary

item.heading: Log Inspection
item.text: The log file should be inspected, but does not necessarily indicate an instrumentation error. Logged errors are usually the result of trying to insert a statement to an invalid location in the parse tree. Please report the issue so that it can be addressed, but you should check whether the instrumented code is actually missing a valid instrumentation line.

For example, if the log contains Error on line 200 of test.js, that line should be inspected. If the code is a multi-line declaration, it may not make sense to add further instrumentation on top of the first line of the declaration.

To speed up the resolution of the issue, try to write a failing test in InstrumenterTest for line coverage and in BranchInstrumentorIntegrationTest for branch coverage. You may even find that you can fix the issue and create a patch for the project.
Finally, if you identify an area where you would like more logging, please open an issue.

item.heading: Report Conversion & Merging
item.text: JSCover's JSON coverage data can be merged together and converted to other formats. This is useful to integrate with other tools - let us know what formats are required. Currently JSCover supports COBERTURAXML (e.g. for Jenkins), XML summary and LCOV report formats.

text.code: java -cp JSCover-all.jar jscover.report.Main --format=[ LCOV | COBERTURAXML ] REPORT-DIR SRC-DIRECTORY
java -cp JSCover-all.jar jscover.report.Main --merge REPORT-DIR1 REPORT-DIR2 REPORT-DIR3...DEST-DIR

tr.td: Output Cobertura XML to REPORT-DIR/cobertura-coverage.xml with source at SRC-DIRECTORY
Output LCOV data to REPORT-DIR/jscover.lcov with source at SRC-DIRECTORY
Merge coverage reports from REPORT-DIR1 REPORT-DIR2 REPORT-DIR3... to DEST-DIR

item.heading: Cobertura XML
item.text:
The Cobertura XML is provided to integrate with Jenkins CI. The XML validates against Cobertura's coverage-04.dtd. Supported elements for coverage metric targets:
coverage totals for all JavaScript files
source path to source (currently only supports one path)
package totals for JavaScript files in the same path
class total for single JavaScript file
line hits for single JavaScript line and total for all conditions on the line
condition coverage for single JavaScript condition
Unsupported elements (which should not affect Jenkins):
methods not populated with method elements
Where there are no branches the branch rate is set to 1.

item.heading: XML Summary
item.text:
The XML summary report records the following totals for easy parsing:
line-rate
branch-rate
lines-covered
lines
branches-covered
branches
timestamp (milliseconds since January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT)
version
<coverage line-rate="0.534072" branch-rate="0.346167" lines-covered="3950" lines="7396" branches-covered="2005" branches="5792" timestamp="1354169242239" version="0.1.0"/>

item.heading: LCOV
item.text: LCOV can be used to generate a HTML coverage report that includes both lines and branch statistics.

If using LCOV with genhtml, SRC-DIRECTORY needs to point to the uninstrumented source on the file system, minus the URI part used with JSCover (i.e. usually the same directory as specified by the --document-root path). For example if YUI3 exists at c:/js/yui3, you would run JSCover with --document-root=c:/js/yui3. JSCover would access yui.js via the path /build/yui/yui.js. JSCover will add the URI path to the SRC-DIRECTORY to create the correct path in the LCOV file (i.e. c:/js/yui3/build/yui/yui.js).

item.heading: Report Merging
item.text: java -cp JSCover-all.jar jscover.report.Main --merge REPORT-DIR1 REPORT-DIR2 REPORT-DIR3...DEST-DIR For example: java -cp JSCover-all.jar jscover.report.Main --merge target/coverage1 target/coverage2 target/total-coverage

item.heading: IFrame Mode
item.text: This is the most commonly used mode, and is described in the Getting Started section above.

item.heading: Window Mode
item.text: In some situations it may be difficult to execute your code within the <iframe> in the JSCover "Browser" tab. For example, the code may assume that it is running in the top-level browser window, generating errors if it is executed from within a frame. JSCover has an alternative mode of operation, called window mode, which may be useful in this case.

To use JSCover in window mode, load your URL by clicking the "Open in window" button instead of the "Open in frame" button. This will cause your URL to be opened in a new window. (Depending on your browser settings, it may be opened in a new browser tab instead.) Execute your code in this new window, and then return to the jscoverage.html window and click the "Summary" tab to get code coverage statistics.

item.heading: Inverted Mode
item.text: There is another alternative mode of operation, called inverted mode. Like window mode, this allows you to avoid running your code inside an <iframe>.

Normally you load jscoverage.html in your web browser, and in its "Browser" tab you launch your test code. In inverted mode, you do the opposite: you load your test page directly in your web browser, and from there you launch JSCover. To do this you need to add some code to your test page: window.open('path/to/jscoverage.html');

The "path/to/jscoverage.html" should be a URL pointing to the location of the jscoverage.html file (remember, this will be in the top level of the DESTINATION-DIRECTORY you specified when running JSCover).
You can place this code wherever you like in your page: for example, you could attach it to a button: <button type="button" onclick="window.open('path/to/jscoverage.html');">Coverage report</button>
Note that you must use a window.open call; simply making a link to jscoverage.html is not sufficient.

item.heading: Query String Options
item.text: When accessing jscoverage.html in a web browser, you may provide a query string consisting of options separated by ampersand (&) or semicolon (;). Any option not containing an equals sign (=) is considered to be a URL which will be loaded in the <iframe> within the "Browser" tab.

u=URL, url=URL, frame=URL, f=URL
Load URL in the <iframe> within the "Browser" tab. (This is the same as specifying an option without an equals sign.)

w=URL, window=URL
Load URL in a new window (window mode).

m=BOOLEAN, missing=BOOLEAN
Determines whether to initially display the "Missing" column in the "Summary" tab. BOOLEAN can be true, t, yes, y, on, 1 (to display the "Missing" column), or false, f, no, n, off, 0 (to hide the "Missing" column). By default, the "Missing" column is not displayed.

item.text: Example of JavaScript to store the report: String jscoverageJson = selenium.getEval("selenium.browserbot.getUserWindow().jscoverage_report();");

item.heading: PhantomJS
item.text: The examples here are for running Jasmine and QUnit tests. Please feel free to send more documentation to this project if you're using PhantomJS in some other way.
Download PhantomJS.
For Jasmine, download run-jscover-jasmine.js, a modified version of PhantomJS's run-jasmine.js.
For QUnit, download run-jscover-qunit.js, a modified version of PhantomJS's run-qunit.js.
Once you have JSCover running in server mode, you can then execute: phantomjs /RUN-JASMINE-PATH/run-jscover-jasmine.js http://localhost:8080/test/javascript/spec/suite.html
This will execute the tests, outputting the test results to the console, and store the coverage results in the 'phantom' sub-directory of JSCover's report directory.

item.heading: Ant
item.text: Example starting the server <target name="JSCover-start"> <java jar="JSCover-all.jar" fork="true" spawn="true"> <arg value="-ws"/> <arg value="--document-root=src"/> <arg value="--report-dir=${jscover.dir}"/> <arg value="--no-instrument=src/main/webapp/js/lib"/> <arg value="--no-instrument=src/test/"/> <arg value="--include-unloaded-js"/> <arg value="--port=8081"/> </java> <waitfor maxwait="5" maxwaitunit="second" checkevery="250" checkeveryunit="millisecond" timeoutproperty="failed"> <http url="http://localhost:8081/jscoverage.html"/> </waitfor> <fail if="failed"/> </target>
Example stopping the server <target name="JSCover-stop"> <get src="http://localhost:8081/stop" dest="${build.dir}/stop.txt" /> </target>

item.text: JSCover's instrumentation has changed from JSCoverage's to more elegantly accommodate other statistics related to a file (including branch coverage).
JSCover _$jscoverage['test.js'].lineData[1]++;
Compare with JSCoverage _$jscoverage['test.js'][1]++;

Features

tr.td: HTML5 Local Storage Alternative to iFrames and JavaScript-opened Windows

item.text:
Other differences include:
JSCover's server mode works on Windows 7 (this was part of the incentive to write JSCover)
JSCover allows sorting of files by coverage and branch coverage
JSCover has added hooks to assist with automated testing
JSCover's encoding default's to that of the platform, while JSCoverage's is ISO-8859-1
JSCover's structure for _$jscoverage is improved, supporting for JSON.stringify and JSON.parse operations
JSCoverage has an option for code coverage for Mozilla platform applications

item.heading: Caveats
item.text:
Caveats
JSCover adds instrumentation to JavaScript code, which will slow down execution speed. Expect instrumented code to take at least twice as much time to run.
JSCover currently instruments only .js files; it does not instrument code in <script> elements in HTML files.
HTML files must use relative URLs to reference scripts. If you use an absolute URL, your page will reference the original uninstrumented script rather than the instrumented one, and no code coverage data will be collected.
JSCover line coverage instruments physical lines of code rather than logical JavaScript statements; it works bests with code that has exactly one statement per line. If you put multiple statements on a line, or split a line across two or more statements, you may get strange results.
JSCover uses frames. Some web pages that use frames may not function properly when run with JSCover, especially those which try to access the top-level frame (window.top, target="_top", etc.).
JSCover proxy currently only supports HTTP, not HTTPS
